### Article 3: ‘GM-free, clean and green’ v climate change: Time for a big call – Simon Wilson

**Source:** [View Full Article](https://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/gm-free-clean-and-green-v-climate-change-time-for-a-big-call-simon-wilson/YHCJSOSC3VFR5LZZS3X2U6COYU/)

## Summary

This article discusses New Zealand's Gene Technology Bill and genetic modification regulations, featuring quotes from Charles Hyland, Chairman of the Soil & Health Association, who testified against the bill citing concerns about food labeling rights and potential contamination risks to organic farming. The content is not related to Hyland Software, the document processing vendor, but rather focuses on agricultural policy and genetic modification debates in New Zealand.

## Executive Insights

**Charles Hyland, Chairman, Soil & Health Association**

> "New Zealanders have a right to know what we're growing and eating – and to choose food that aligns with their values."

*Context: Testimony to select committee regarding the Gene Technology Bill*

*Significance: Represents opposition perspective on genetic modification regulations in New Zealand*

**Charles Hyland, Chairman, Soil & Health Association**

> "This bill would still allow GE [genetic engineering] into our farms, gardens and food, risking contamination, loss of organic certification, lawsuits and Aotearoa's GE-free status. Anyone who doesn't want GE could face difficulties avoiding it."

*Context: Further testimony expressing concerns about the Gene Technology Bill's potential impacts*

*Significance: Outlines specific risks and concerns from organic food industry perspective*
